Species_Processed: common reed (Phragmites australis); smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora)
Trait_Processed: Invasive history of P. australis individuals, associated with genetic lineage
Shift_Processed: Differential effects of lineages on soil biota changes the outcome of a pathogen/mutualist spillover (apparent competition-mutualism) interaction between species

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype of Cr. modiglianii (tendency to initiate a nest, foraging, trail following, nest defence)
Shift_Processed: Interaction of C. modiglianii with C. rufifemur shifts towards a parabiosis/apparent mutualism, when conditions are suitable for nest cohabitation (e.g. with the presence of an epiphyte),  with likely changes in C. modiglianii nest defence and foraging behaviour

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype of T. truncatus (foraging behaviour, human cooperativeness)
Shift_Processed: Variation in cooperative behaviour/foraging behaviour linked to variation from a competitive to a beneficial interaction with human fisherman

Species_Processed: Wyoming Indian paintbrush (Castilleja linariaefolia); broad-tailed hummingbird (Selasphorus platycercus); rufous hummingbird (Selasphorus rufus); plume moth (Platyptilia pica); leaf-miner flies (genus Phytomyza)
Trait_Processed: Morphological traits in C. linariaefolia (calyx length, flower production, plant height)
Shift_Processed: Variation in morphological traits reduce the strength of mutualistic interactions with animals (e.g. pollination) and increase antagonistic interactions (e.g. flower resource exploitation without pollination)

Species_Processed: valley oak (Quercus lobata); California scrub-jay (Aphelocoma californica); acorn woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus)
Trait_Processed: Reproductive traits in Q. lobata (Seed production and availability)
Shift_Processed: Variation in seed production can favor mutualistic (e.g. seed dispersal), or antagonistic (seed predation) interactions with animal community

Species_Processed: Canary Island foxglove (Isoplexis canariensis); various mutualistic/antagonistic animal species
Trait_Processed: Position of plant within local community (likely associated with dispersal traits)
Shift_Processed: More central plants derived greater mutualistic benefits from animal interactions (e.g. pollination success)

Species_Processed: baishan fir (Abies beshanzuensis); endophytic fungi community (subkingdom Dikarya)
Trait_Processed: Chemical defence traits of Dikarya fungi (ligninolytic enzyme production), linked to laccase genes
Shift_Processed: Substantial variation in chemical traits within fungi species, which under certain condition may enhance nutrient-access provide fitness benefits for the host, or act as a parasite

Species_Processed: common crayfish (Cambarus bartonii); Cambarincola philadelphicus (Clitellata); Cambarincola ingens (Clitellata)
Trait_Processed: Body size of C. bartonii; Feeding behaviour of symbiont
Shift_Processed: Mutualistic symbiont can begin feeding on the hosts gills when food limited, particularly smaller crayfish who are less able to remove them

Trait_Processed: Variation in reproductive traits between A. tabida populations
Shift_Processed: Differences in reproduction between populations, where some are reliant on wolbachia, and others wolbachia infection provides no reproductive benefit

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype of P. carabi (feeding); Sex/age differences in N. vespilloides linked to trait differences
Shift_Processed: Variation in P. carabi feeding behaviour shifts mutualistic interaction towards antagonistic, linked with density; Balance of male-female and parent-offspring interaction shifts as a result of mite infection, due to differential effects of infection on fitness

Species_Processed: Eurasian penduline tit (Remiz pendulinus); Cape penduline tit (Anthoscopus minutus)
Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (level of parental care, desertion), attractiveness and song complexity in R. pendulinus
Shift_Processed: Individual R. pendulinus males show behavioural differences in level of conflict-cooperation within breeding pair, where male attractiveness shifts the quality of the male-female  interaction

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (level of parental care, desertion), physiological condition and attractiveness
Shift_Processed: Individuals show behavioural differences in level of conflict-cooperation within breeding pair, where male attractiveness and condition change the likelihood of male or female abandonment

Trait_Processed: Reproductive behaviour of males (courtship strategy, female oviposition puncture rate)
Shift_Processed: Individual males and females vary in reproductive behaviour that shifts the balance of sexual conflict between cooperation and conflict, where low food availability promotes a cooperative strategy

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (participation in coordinated aggressive responses)
Shift_Processed: Individuals show variation in their participation in coordinated, cooperative territory defence of breeding pairs, driven by the level of threat posed

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (turn-taking, parental care, socio-positive behaviour)
Shift_Processed: Variation in breeding partner's participation in cooperative breeding and foraging for offspring, driven by state-dependent effects on behaviour

Trait_Processed: Social dominance (related traits that determine male competitive ability)
Shift_Processed: Composition of male competitive traits determines the distribution of reproductive success (reproductive skew), where degree of skew shows variation in the level cooperation-conflict between group males, and variation in sexual conflict due to effects on female choice

Species_Processed: Viviparous lizard (Lacerta vivipara); Side-blotched lizards (genus Uta)
Trait_Processed: Morphological, physiological, behavioural morphs of male L. vivipara, linked by composition of genetic alleles
Shift_Processed: Morphs show varying levels of cooperation-conflict between conspecifics and sexes, where there is temporal variation in composition of morphs due to the relative success of each morph in a rock-paper-scissors dynamic

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (aggression)
Shift_Processed: Variation in the aggression at an individual level is associated with variation in the level of cooperation-competition within social groups

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype of males (helping behaviour), body condition and age
Shift_Processed: Variation in male participation in reproductive helping behaviour, linked with age/body condition and influenced by in ecological conditions, shifting the interaction quality between group members and male-females in cooperative breeding groups

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (responsiveness to begging)
Shift_Processed: Variation in responsiveness to offspring begging in cooperative breeding groups, driven by state-dependent effects in the body condition of helpers

Trait_Processed: Behavioural (movement and foraging) and physiological (thermal insulation) phenotypes
Shift_Processed: Spatial variation is the level of swarming behaviour (cooperative) and swarming repulsion (competitive) interactions across within and between species of grazing herbivore, partially driven by density

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (host searching strategy)
Shift_Processed: Predation pressure disproportionately effects responder (cheating) phenotype, so that intraspecific interactions between conspecifics in host searching between become more cooperative

Trait_Processed: Variation in individual 'value' related to access to food resources
Shift_Processed: Individuals of higher 'value' are more likely to be reconciled with following an aggressive conflict, i.e. variation in conflict-cooperation linked to individual variation in resource-related traits

Species_Processed: European paper wasp (Polistes dominulus); tropical hover wasp (Liostenogaster flavolineata)
Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (helping behaviour)
Shift_Processed: Variation in helping behaviour in eusocial groups showing among-individual variation in cooperative-competitive interactions within the group, depending on the future fitness expectation of the individual

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype of female fountresses (sociality, aggression, resource investment in colony)
Shift_Processed: Variation between regions in social and nonsocial phenotypes in cooperative-competitive interactions with other females, with both types showing some change in their level of sociability/aggression based on the type female it was interacting with

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype of female fountresses (sociality, aggression), linked to genetic variation
Shift_Processed: Variation between regions in social and nonsocial phenotypes in cooperative-competitive interactions with other females

Trait_Processed: Sporulation and swarming intensity/frequency, linked to genetic strains
Shift_Processed: Variation between strains is associated with varying levels of cooperative-competitive interactions between individual bacteria

Trait_Processed: Allorecognition (likelihood to fuse with or reject conspecific), linked with genetic alleles
Shift_Processed: Variation is associated with formation of cooperative colonies, or rejection, so more intraspecific variation is associated with a reduced likelihood of cooperation

Trait_Processed: Reproductive strategy of males (coalition forming or one-on-one competition)
Shift_Processed: Variation in reproductive strategy shows variation between conflict and cooperation with between males, varies due to state-dependent effect of age and condition

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype of males (aggression)
Shift_Processed: Variation in the aggression at an individual level is associated with variation in the level of cooperation-competition within social groups

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (sociality, solitary or group living)
Shift_Processed: Variation in living strategy is associated with different levels social cooperation-competition, driven by variation in population density and reproductive competition

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (strategy, decision making)
Shift_Processed: Variation in choice of cooperative or anti-cooperative strategy, show among and within-individual variation in strategy linked to the benefit/payoff of different scenarios

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (sociality), relatedness
Shift_Processed: Variation in the level of sociality linked to cooperative-antagonistic social interactions (e.g. warren sharing), driven by environment variation in altering the relative costs of cooperative-antagonistic behaviours

Trait_Processed: Behavioural phenotype (initiation/receive cooperative interactions), linked with sex, age and body size
Shift_Processed: Variation in cooperative behavioural phenotypes linked to differential participation mutualistic-antagonistic social interactions

Trait_Processed: Variation in social status or affiliation
Shift_Processed: Variation in an individual's social affiliations is linked to variation between cooperative-antagonistic social interactions, due to transitivity effects of 3rd party affiliations on social interactions

Trait_Processed: Body size, behavioural phenotype (aggression)
Shift_Processed: Variation in size is associated with increased antagonism to other individuals, less cooperation in the formation of stable social hierarchies to occupy and share resources on sponge habitat patches
